repnme.cdata!: Saint Lucia - Poverty Reduction Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Poverty Reduction Fund Project for
            Saint Lucia had the following ratings: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that the social investment fund concept can
            work as vehicle to achieve poverty reduction in small island
            countries. Communities can manage key aspects of the
            subproject cycle, and this contributes to local capacity and
            ownership. Building lasting and greater social capital is a
            long-term process. Capacity building is critical, but should
            be linked as much as possible to the labor market. Project
            design should consider the long start-up time for new
            entities. Good managers with decision-making autonomy, and
            adequate staffing, are key to successful implementation.
            Community participation fosters the appropriate selection of
            subprojects. Appropriate design and timing of monitoring and
            evaluation instruments is crucial to monitoring project
            impacts. A communications strategy would benefit the Poverty
            Reduction Fund (PRF). Duplication of donor efforts continues
            to be a concern and requires careful consideration by the
            World Bank. Diseconomies of scale in small states affects
            project performance.

5084637.trustfund:
TF038207-BELIZE SIF AND ST. LUCIA
            POVERTY REDUCTION FUND,TF040901-ST. LUCIA: POVERTY REDUCTION FUND
5084637.majtheme: Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!: Saint Lucia - Poverty Reduction Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Poverty Reduction Fund Project aims
            at developing the institutional and operational framework
            for a social fund model, and pilot its ability to increase
            access to, and provide quality of basic social and economic
            infrastructure, and services, among St. Lucia's
            vulnerable poor. The project will thus contribute to a
            sustainable infrastructure, fostering community-led
            development. The project components include: 1)
            institutional strengthening for poverty reduction, to
            further increase the role and responsibilities of
            communities in the subproject cycle development, including
            subproject management, and strengthening promotion
            mechanisms. This component will include the establishment of
            appropriate methodologies and criteria of the subproject
            cycle, in accordance with all relevant parties involved in
            poverty reduction; 2) subproject financing, which will
            mobilize external co-financing, with possible support from
            other agencies, such as the Caribbean Development Bank and
            the European Union. Subproject implementation will include
            social and economic infrastructure, technical assistance and
            capacity-building for social assistance programs; 3) project
            management costs, to cover the execution of the design
            phase, and implementation, as well as monitoring and evaluation.
